title: Nepeta grandiflora
text:
Nepeta grandiflora is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the mint <a href="family%20%28botany%29">family</a> Lamiaceae, native to the <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>. Growing to tall by , it is a clump-forming, erect <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> <a href="herbaceous">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial</a> with aromatic, slightly hairy, grey-green leaves, and spikes of purple/blue flowers in early summer. Species of "Nepeta" are called <a href="catnip">catnip</a> or catmint, with reference to their reported effect on some domestic cats. The plants seem to induce a euphoria in the animals, causing them to roll in the foliage and exhibit signs of intoxication.
"N. grandiflora" and its <a href="cultivar">cultivar</a>s are widely grown as ornamental garden plants which are useful for the middle of a flower border in full sun. The cultivar ‘Bramdean’ has gained the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a>’s <a href="Award%20of%20Garden%20Merit">Award of Garden Merit</a>.
